text: the first interesting thing I would say
is that you know several years later the
Facebook data science team actually did
the thing that was inconceivable to me
back in the in the late 1990s that they
took a billion people on Facebook and
all of their friends and they just
countered by brute force how many steps
it takes to get from anyone to anyone
else and in fact it's always less than
six so so the numbers a pretty good
number but it really the larger point I
think is that is that you we have new
ways of looking at old problems now just
because you have this data just because
you have new types of instruments that
allow you to measure things that you
couldn't measure before you can develop
entirely new approaches that would have
been quite impossible in you know in a
previous era and I think sort of in
general you know advances in science or
revolutions in science are often
preceded by innovations in
instrumentation you build a new kind of
instrument you invent the telescope it
allows you to sort of see into deep
space for the first time and it
completely changes astronomy and then it
changes cosmology and physics and so
many other things you you invent a
microscope and allows you to see
bacteria swarming around inside a cell
and it changes biology and you know
there are all kinds of flaws in this
analogy but there's some element of
truth to it that we are you know the
internet and digital data is in some
sense akin to the telescope that we are
we have built an instrument that allows
us to make previously invisible things
visible and that should be useful for
lots of things and we'll talk more about
all the ways in which it is an imperfect
analogy and there are all kinds of
problems but there's clearly something
there and it's already having a huge
effect on the social sciences and will
continue to do so
you
[Music]
